p: In X. tropicalis, body size predicted jump force ( t = 5.44, P < 0.001) and individual identity explained part of the variance (standard deviations: intercept, 0.16; residuals, 0.60). Xenopus tropicalis had a higher jump force when measured at a test temperature of 24°C compared to a higher test temperature (test: X 2 = 18.97, P < 0.001), but this effect was dependent on the acclimation treatment (acclimation *test: X 2 = 12.69, P < 0.001). Individuals acclimated at 24°C had a 60% higher jump force when measured at the same test temperature compared to a high temperature ( t = 5.56, P < 0.001; Fig. 1A), but when individuals were acclimated at a high temperature, their jump force was not dependent on the test temperature ( t = 0.56, P = 0.58).
